stories.text:
As a self-employed senior software developer, I mostly live off selected freelance work, aside from varying income through SaaS products and apps.

I get 100% of inbound work through recommendations in my personal network. Because of that, I have never had a rate negotiation, had to pitch my skills or expertise, or bid against others.

But, there's a huge problem in managing work load:

Sometimes, I go WEEKS without a single hour billed. Other times, I need to decline two projects at once because I am still knuckle-deep in another one.

Which reminded me of "agents":

I would actually be happy to pay someone a fee for managing this. I published a book a few years ago, and my book agent essentially took care of the pitching, the leads, getting it sold. I 'just' did the writing.

The TV agent model seems to be even more applicable. You have "preference on work, clients, scale and scope", and they try to fill up your unbooked time with projects that match. For each booked gig, they charge a fee.

Does that exist? Would that be possible? The main argument against it seems to be developer hesitance against out-of-network clients (and risk), and the agent over-promising on both ends to make the deal happen.

Sites like UpWork don't really solve this (for me), because I don't want to compete just on price and star ratings. Every client is happy with the work, attitude, communication and my price, but if I had to compete with a 100,000 developers out there who charge 1/10th of my price, it'll be tough (clearly a first world problem, I know, I know).

Just curious how you do this. I am trying to cap freelance work at 50% of my week, with most projects being < 6 months.

I partially worry what would happen if my network stops delivering work, and I already worry about managing the inconsistent volume coming in.

Like, a load balancer for project work. Thoughts?
stories.title: Ask HN: The case for middle men in freelancing, do agents exist?
